output.conclusion: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of telecommunication switching principles and technologies, equipping advanced learners with the knowledge and skills to design, analyze, and manage modern telecommunication networks.
output.introduction: Welcome to Telecommunication Switching! This advanced-level course delves into the core principles and technologies behind modern telecommunication networks. We will explore various switching techniques, network architectures, and signaling protocols, providing you with a deep understanding of how voice, data, and multimedia traffic are efficiently routed and managed.

chapters.description: Overview of telecommunication networks and their evolution. Basic switching functions: concentration, expansion, and distribution. Classification of switching systems: circuit switching, packet switching, and message switching.
Time-division multiplexing (TDM) and space-division multiplexing (SDM). Crossbar switches and multi-stage switches. Blocking probability and grade of service (GoS) in circuit switching networks.
In-band and out-of-band signaling. Common channel signaling (CCS) and Signaling System No. 7 (SS7). Call setup, call teardown, and supplementary services.
Principles of packet switching: store-and-forward, routing, and flow control. Virtual circuit switching and datagram switching. Comparison of circuit switching and packet switching.
Distance-vector routing and link-state routing. Routing protocols: RIP, OSPF, and BGP. Congestion control and quality of service (QoS) in packet switching networks.
Shared-memory switches, shared-medium switches, and space-division switches. Input-queued switches and output-queued switches. Performance analysis of packet switching fabrics.
Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM) architecture and protocol stack. ATM cell format and switching principles. Quality of service (QoS) provisioning in ATM networks.
Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS) architecture and label distribution protocols. Traffic engineering and virtual private networks (VPNs) using MPLS. Comparison of ATM and MPLS.
Ethernet frame format and MAC address learning. Spanning tree protocol (STP) and VLANs. Gigabit Ethernet and 10 Gigabit Ethernet switching.
SDN architecture and control plane/data plane separation. OpenFlow protocol and SDN controllers. Network virtualization and network function virtualization (NFV).
Cloud computing and its impact on telecommunication networks. Virtual switches and software-based routers. Network orchestration and automation in the cloud.
Emerging technologies: 5G, IoT, and edge computing. Challenges and opportunities in telecommunication switching. Research directions in switching and networking.
